title: 100-1 Appendices
summary: Don's autobiographical reflection on formative educational literature including A.S. Neill's "The Free Child" (Summerhill school philosophy); "The Eight Year Study" (high school-college longitudinal research 1933-1941 showing innovative schools matched traditional schools academically while exceeding in non-academic life); Werner Z. Federal service with Canada Employment and Immigration included teacher training specialist role. Holland College presidency 1969-1987 established competency-based education, Atlantic Police Academy, Culinary Institute of Canada, Centre for Creativity. title: Electric Power

Includes memory of his mother's electric iron, kept in storage during prior years when his father worked at hydroelectric dam projects with electricity access.

title: Together in USA
summary: Comprehensive historical narrative of Glendenning and Watling families' migration to USA and establishment in Tennessee during 1910-1913. Opens with post-WW2 context of Maritimer emigration patterns (woods work in Maine/New Hampshire initially, then year-round settlement). Describes Portland's historical significance as Atlantic & St. Lawrence Railroad terminus ("Canada's winter port"), industrial development (locomotives, docks, construction jobs), 1866 fire (1500 buildings destroyed, 12,000 homeless), Promenade grand homes. Chronicles Glendenning family's Portland settlement with siblings' roles and occupations. Extensively documents Elmer and Frank's cartage business (Glendenning Bros. & Co., 24 Hammond Street, ice delivery, general team work). Details Elmer's work progression in woods (Maine/New Hampshire near Skowhegan, Millinocket, Berlin; lumbering with horses; record lumber cut). Parallels with Jane Watling's Portland arrival (January 24, 1908, City Hall fire day), employment as nanny/housekeeper with Jennison family. Covers marriage ceremony (October 18, 1910 at Little Branch home of parents by Rev. George Grant), honeymoon in Montreal, residence in Bonny Eagle, Maine. Describes Jane's household journal/purchase record (January 1911 entries documenting domestic economy). Extensive section on Parksville, Tennessee: geographic/historic context (Polk County, Ocoee River, southeast of Chattanooga); technical details on dam construction (Ocoee No. 1 and No. 2 developments, Tennessee Power Authority documents); construction timeline (August 1910 commencement, February 1911 concrete placement, January 27, 1912 plant start); employment scale (1500+ workers); infrastructure (constructed town with waterworks, stores, hospital, police); concrete placement rates (12-15 hundred cubic yards daily). Details relocation from Ocoee No. 1 to Ocoee No. 2 (Caney Creek, May-October 1912). Contains repeated sections (FILE 8 duplicates FILE 5 and FILE 6 content).
